node.title: Why has it taken so long to crack down on cosmetic cowboys?
node.alt: Dr Daniel Lanzer gestures with his hands while talking on the set of a tv show. He is wearing a surgeon's scrubs.
node.description: In a major win for Australian patients, the medical regulator AHPRA this week announced its first ever review into patient safety in the cosmetic surgery sector. But the problems with the multi-billion-dollar industry have been well known by authorities for decades, writes Lauren Day.Â
node.content:
["In a major win for Australian patients, the medical regulator AHPRA this week announced its first-ever review into patient safety in the cosmetic surgery sector.\u00a0", "It comes in the wake of a joint Four Corners investigation with the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age that uncovered allegations of disturbing practices at the clinics of celebrity cosmetic surgeon Dr Daniel Lanzer, including hygiene and safety breaches and procedures that left patients with ongoing physical and psychological issues.", "But the problems with the multi-billion-dollar cosmetic procedures industry have been well known by authorities for decades.", "As early as 1999, the NSW Health Care Complaints Commission recommended a credential\u00a0system for cosmetic surgeons that included adequate surgical training provided by the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons.", "This never happened.", "The report also recommended data be collected centrally on complications and complaints.", "Shockingly, this still doesn't happen.", "The term cosmetic surgeon is not protected by law, which means the regulator can't police it. The upshot is anyone with a basic medical degree can call themselves a cosmetic surgeon and do facelifts, tummy tucks and other complex invasive body-altering surgery.", "In 2019, state health ministers met and agreed to further consultation to restrict the use of the title \"surgeon\", including those who call themselves \"cosmetic surgeons\" with no specialised accreditation.", "They are still consulting.", "", "
Watch the Four Corners investigation into the unregulated world of cosmetic surgery.
", "It took brave patients and whistleblowers Justin Nixon and Lauren Hewish, who worked at celebrity cosmetic surgeon Dr Daniel Lanzer's clinics, to speak up in a joint Four Corners investigation with The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age, to finally get some results.", "The regulator's wide-ranging external review into cosmetic surgery will include better ways to protect patients, the use of social media by some cosmetic surgeons to promote their services, and why medical practitioners aren't fulfilling their mandatory requirements and reporting the complications they have to fix.", "During the joint Four Corners investigation with the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age, a consistent theme that emerged was shame and embarrassment.", "But it wasn't shame from the doctors the allegations were levelled against, or the regulator that patients say failed to protect them.", "It was the patients themselves.", "Many felt embarrassed, even responsible, that their own vanity might be to blame for the horrendous outcomes they suffered.", "They feared judgement over the fact that a medical procedure they chose to have in fact caused medical issues.", "As noted by AHPRA chief executive\u00a0Martin Fletcher while announcing the regulator's review, cosmetic surgery has some \"worrying features\" that\u00a0sets it apart from other areas of medicine.", "\"Among them, corporate business models that are allegedly placing profit over patient safety, procedures being undertaken for no medical need, limited factual information for consumers and the exponential growth in social media that often emphasises benefits and downplays risks.\"", "This is true, and the review into the sector has been welcomed by patients and doctors alike.", "However, cosmetic surgery patients are patients, and all Australian patients should be able to expect reasonable care and a system that protects them from both misinformation and harm.", "Many will be wondering why this review took so long.", "You can watch the full investigation on ABC iview."]
